name: AIM 65
ram: 4 KB (up to 32 KB of static RAM)
ports: Application bus, expansion bus, ROM connector
power: Needs four power supply voltages: +5v, +12v, -12v, and +24v for the printer
description:
This strange computer was designed to be a development system for 6502 based computers. It had no display except for a small 20 character LED screen and a very small thermal printer located directly on the motherboard which could print everything that was typed on the keyboard.

The board featured five 4 KB-ROM sockets. Two of them were dedicated to the AIM monitor program, including an instant input assembler (no labels) and a disassembler. Various programming languages (BASIC, FORTH...) or custom applications could be added in the three remaining sockets.

Several cards were developped for this machine, especially language cards and ROMs: a BASIC card (BASIC language with floating point mathematics capabilities), PL/65 (a mixture of the PL/1 and Algol languages), Instant Pascal (an interpreted version of Pascal), Assembler and the FORTH programming language.
_______________________

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD EXPLAINED</strong></font><br><blockquote>The AIM-65 was intended to be used for external device control and management. Its two extension connectors give access to all the control signals of the board. Used for this purpose, a one line display and a small printer are sufficient. <br><br> <b>(1)</b> This connector allows the AIM-65 to be connected to an external device and to manage it. <br> <b>(2)</b> VIA-6522 chipset in charge of two I/O ports control. <br> <b>(3)</b> Expansion connector. It can receive an expansion unit or a memory board. <br> <b>(4)</b> 8 chips holding 4 Kb RAM of which 3 are available for user programs. <br> <b>(5)</b> Microprocessor 6502 from MOS technology. <br> <b>(6)</b> Sockets for additional ROM chips (for programming languages or specific software).<br> <b>(7)</b> 2 ROM chips holding the AIM-65 monitor.<br> <b>(8)</b> 20 characters LED display. An external monitor can be used with an optional interface. <br> <b>(9)</b> Switch to turn the computer in step-by-step mode, where each microprocessor instruction is performed step by step.<br> <b>(10)</b> Mechanical ASCII Keyboard. <br> <b>(11)</b> 6532 chipset in charge of the keyboard management. <br> <b>(12)</b> System init button (Reset). <br> <b>(13)</b> 20 char./line thermal printer. <br> <b>(14)</b> Power plug. An external power supply is needed.</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing is very simple with the AIM65 from Rockwell"</blockquote>
